item.title: Economic data in motion
item.description: if(!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") ## Loading required package: pacman p_load("tidyverse", "tidyquant", "gganimate", "bbplot") tickers <- c("LRHUTTTTFRM156S", "LRHUTTTTDEM156S", "LRHUTTTTUSM156S", "LRHUTTTTJPM156S") countries_name <- c("France", "Germany", "United States", "Japan") unemployment_lst <- list() for(i in seq_along(tickers)){ unemployment_lst[[i]] <- tq_get(tickers[i], get = "economic.data", from = "2000-01-01", to = "2018-11-01") %>% mutate(symbol = countries_name[i]) } unemployment_tbl <- do.call(rbind, unemployment_lst) p <- unemployment_tbl %>% ggplot(aes(x = date, y = price, fill = symbol)) + geom_area(stat="identity") + labs(title = "Harmonized Unemployment Rate: Total: All Persons", subtitle = "France, Germany, Japan and United States", y = "Unemployment", x = "Year") + scale_fill_discrete(name = " ") + theme_tq() + facet_wrap(~symbol, ncol = 2) p + transition_reveal(date) + shadow_mark()

item.title: Road to oscars 2019
item.description: if(!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") p_load("tidyverse", "rvest", "bbplot", "ggalt") oscar_movies <- read_html("https://www.imdb.com/list/ls023438886/?st_dt=&mode=detail&page=1&ref_=ttls_vm_dtl&sort=list_order,asc") matrix_value <- matrix(0, nrow = 36, ncol = 4) colnames(matrix_value) <- c("movie_name", "date", "imdb_score", "metacritic_score") for(i in 1:36){ seudo_link <- "#main > div > div.lister.list.detail.sub-list > div.lister-list > div:nth-child" selector <- c("a", "span.lister-item-year.text-muted.unbold") for(j in 1:2){ matrix_value[i,j] <- oscar_movies %>% html_nodes(paste0(seudo_link,"(",i,") ","> div.lister-item-content > h3 > ",selector[j])) %>% html_text() %>% as.character() } matrix_value[i,3] <- oscar_movies %>% html_nodes(paste0(seudo_link,"(",i,") ","> div.lister-item-content > div.ipl-rating-widget > div.

item.title: How BBC visualize data?
item.description: if(!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") ## Loading required package: pacman p_load("tidyverse", "bbplot", "readxl", "viridis", "wesanderson") ## Installing package into 'C:/Users/Habac/Documents/R/win-library/3.5' ## (as 'lib' is unspecified) ## Warning: unable to access index for repository http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/pub/RWin/bin/windows/contrib/3.5: ## no fue posible abrir la URL 'http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/pub/RWin/bin/windows/contrib/3.5/PACKAGES' ## package 'wesanderson' successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked ## ## The downloaded binary packages are in ## C:\Users\Habac\AppData\Local\Temp\RtmpaG8SHD\downloaded_packages ## ## wesanderson installed imdb_tbl <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheEconomist/graphic-detail-data/master/data/2018-11-24_tv-ratings/IMDb_Economist_tv_ratings.csv") imdb_tbl_1 <- imdb_tbl %>% group_by(titleId) %>% mutate(number_season = n()) %>% filter(row_number(titleId) == 1) %>% select(titleId, title, number_season) %>% arrange(desc(number_season)) %>% ungroup() %>% group_by(number_season) %>% mutate(n = n()) %>% filter(row_number() == 1) %>% ungroup() %>% mutate(percent = n/sum(n), season = paste0("S", number_season)) %>% arrange(desc(percent)) %>% filter(n >= 15) g <- ggplot(imdb_tbl_1, aes(x = season, y = percent)) + geom_bar(colour = "black", stat = "identity", position = "identity", fill = "orange") + geom_hline(yintercept = 0, size = 1, colour="#333333") + bbc_style() + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) + theme(axis.

item.title: One of the New Feature of ggplot2 3.0
item.description: Why this post? Some time ago Dina Pomeranz posted on twitter a brief article about how the gender gaps has been falling in most countries, if you don’t believe me: The unadjusted gender wage gap for full time workers has been falling significantly in most countries: https://t.co/k7olIo40ZA pic.twitter.com/uknetWXajw — Dina D. Pomeranz (@DinaPomeranz) July 4, 2018 After reading the post1, I decided to replicate the entire article using the new features of ggplot2 3.

item.title: Tópicos en Economía & Negocios Utilizando R ➡️ 👽 + 🇪🇸
item.description: Descripción Curso Este curso presenta una introducción a R, usando datos estructurados y no estructurados, relacionados a economía, finanzas y marketing. Entre los tópicos a discutir se encuentran: importación y exportación de datos en diferentes formatos, extracción de datos de sitios web, visualización de datos, regresión lineal, simulación de Monte Carlo y construcción de aplicaciones web utilizando Shiny. Presentaciones & Tutoriales Todas las presentaciones fueron confeccionadas usando la librería Xaringan de Yihui Xie con el tema Dharma-Xaringan, creado por mí ✌️ (ver post).
